SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He attributes this to the change in seasons and increased activity due to home renovations. The patient also reports feeling bloated occasionally and experiencing shortness of breath during exertion. He denies fever, chills, and chest pain but endorses a slight cough. The patient has been monitoring his blood pressure at home and has been adhering to his medications.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain. Endorses shortness of breath on exertion.
• Respiratory: Positive cough. Positive shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Positive bloating.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by the physical examination and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and call if weight gain or shortness of breath occurs. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Instruct the patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is present with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation is noted in the lower extremity. No calf pain is reported.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment appears normal.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he heard a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat, but these did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies joint pain or swelling.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes, resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation at lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening and pain management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are elevated.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril to 20 mg once daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He states that his depression is well-managed.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. He reports his blood pressure has been mostly okay.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He denies any significant shortness of breath except during high pollen season and when running in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath at rest, mild shortness of breath with exertion.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle aches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, well-managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Well-controlled at 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill prescription for Prozac.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well-controlled in the office.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: No concerning findings on chest X-ray, patient exercising regularly.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls four days ago.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She had a colonoscopy about 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Patient is alert and oriented.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of anemia since the age of 13 and is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If these tests are inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered. We will recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist, Dr. Flores, for further evaluation and possible intravenous iron treatment or other interventions to improve iron storage.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient is advised to take her iron pills with orange juice to enhance iron absorption. She should continue this for 8-12 weeks and then we can reassess her blood work.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward, a 52-year-old male, presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile demonstrating a low TSH, and an MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 revealing a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The patient has been experiencing headaches located behind his eyes, with a gradual onset and worsening severity over time. He also reports bumping into door frames recently.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. Non-smoker, non-drinker, and no recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert and oriented. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficits in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery for pituitary adenoma excision and decompression of the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

End of note.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient reports experiencing chest pain in early October 2020, which lasted for four days and has not recurred since. She visited the ER during this time, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, both of which were normal. The patient reports difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has also resolved. She denies any recent abdominal pain and reports normal bowel movements. She has been trying to lose weight and was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain episode.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

RESULTS

EKG and blood tests from the ER visit were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal causes, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms have resolved, and she has not experienced any recurrence. It is suspected that she may have had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contributions from musculoskeletal causes.

The patient was offered the option of an EGD or upper endoscopy to investigate her esophagus and stomach, but given the resolution of her symptoms and the time elapsed since the episode, she elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Possible kidney anomalies related to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting today for evaluation of possible kidney anomalies. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies related to her syndrome.

The patient's mother reports that Katherine has approximately 8-10 wet diapers per day and drinks a significant amount of fluids, including water and non-dairy milk. Katherine has a twin sister who is developing normally.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Not assessed.
• Cardiovascular: Not assessed.
• Respiratory: Not assessed.
• Gastrointestinal: History of reflux and feeding difficulties.
• Genitourinary: 8-10 wet diapers per day.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Neurological: Developmental delays, history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
• Eyes: Small appearing eyes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting today for evaluation of possible kidney anomalies.

• Medical Reasoning: Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for patients with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
• Additional Testing: We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today.
• Follow-up: If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

Patient Agreements: The patient's mother understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no thyromegaly, no adenopathy.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
MSK: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a fist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient her current symptoms and diagnosis. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace for her right wrist. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will wear the brace for six weeks and attend physical therapy three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in one month to assess her progress and determine if she can proceed with her planned vacation. If there are any concerns or worsening of symptoms, the patient should contact the office immediately.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, currently on 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Edema and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing pain and swelling in the right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to elevate and stay off the injured leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is elevated at 150/70 mmHg and has a history of hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril and refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant male patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the shoulder. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to feel like she might fall. This occurs less than once a day and resolves quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for pain as it does not last long. The patient is concerned about her knee giving out during an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and participating in line dancing.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports controlled blood pressure with medication.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension, controlled with medication.
3. Diabetes mellitus, slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage. Encourage the patient to continue monitoring blood sugars and taking medications as prescribed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports having a good support system from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports mild fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat, no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting, reports decreased appetite.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles in lungs bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, likely related to radiation.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen of cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles in lungs are likely due to mild radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat is likely due to inflammation in the esophagus from radiation.
- Medical Treatment: In addition to prednisone, prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to help with pain relief and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger for a long time. No recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. Patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies. Family is generally healthy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient recently traveled to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits, no fever.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without knowing they have it. Some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections, but this does not seem to be the case for the patient.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check other antibodies to rule out other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency with the patient and advised them to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. Informed the patient to notify healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed by primary care physician. Encourage moderation in diet and lifestyle.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He has been doing a lot of pottery recently and believes this may have contributed to the pain. The pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and ability to perform certain activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the following plan:
1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for one week.
4. Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up appointment in one week to evaluate progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent dietary indiscretion.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily, but admits to occasional missed doses.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion.
Genitourinary: No complaints.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Lung Examination: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes with difficulty finding a comfortable position. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief with minimal effect. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Urinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone (acute nephrolithiasis).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol as needed.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. He initially experienced stinging and burning sensations, but now describes the pain as throbbing. The ulcer has a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened edges. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with 2-3 days remaining in the course. He reports a fever of 99.7°F and chills before starting antibiotics. He also reports calf muscle cramping and red streaks along the inside portion of his calf muscle. His blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks, with a spike up to 500-600 at one point.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, changing the inserts every 3-4 months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills before starting antibiotics.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and difficulty catching breath when walking around the house.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No headaches or numbness/tingling in feet.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Not provided
RESPIRATORY: Not provided
NECK: Not provided
MSK: Examination of the right foot: 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler. No pain on palpation of the affected area.

RESULTS
Imaging

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes
3. Diabetic neuropathy

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed the assessment and plan with the patient. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound. I will perform a debridement in the office today and obtain a culture to guide antibiotic therapy. The patient will continue his current antibiotic course, with potential adjustments based on culture results. He will follow up with his endocrinologist to ensure proper diabetes management and maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7. We will closely monitor the redness and swelling in his calf and schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with erythema and edema.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient spends time outdoors, including hunting and working in the yard.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history mentioned.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain, but no new joint pain.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not mentioned
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee. Full range of motion.

Skin
- Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Presence of tick bite, bull's-eye rash, and general malaise.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on lisinopril.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order lipid panel.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of diabetes and is currently on metformin.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order hemoglobin A1C and basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
